frameDefinitions: An Exerter, Action, or Force is capable of exerting or does exert a physical force at a level specified by the target.
The words in this frame describe acts (or situations characterized by acts) that cause injury or harm.

In this frame a Hindrance makes it more difficult for a Protagonist to complete their intended Action or a Hindrance directly affects an Action where the Action can be a natural act or the actions of many individuals in a collective endeavor.

This frame is concerned with the idea that people (Participant_1, Participant_2, or Participants) participate in an organized, rule-governed activity (the Competition) in order to achieve some advantageous outcome (often the Prize).
An Experiencer has an easy or difficult time carrying out an Activity.
A Resisting_entity is capable of resisting or does resist a physical Opposing_force to a level specified by the target.
frameExamples: Eugenie loved the sea and was a <t>strong</t> swimmer.
Research on whether concealed carry laws increase gun <t>violence</t> among gang members has been inconclusive.
Malcolm was <t>hindered</t> by his drinking problem .
The great and <t>impregnable</t> fortress still stands today.
listRoleDefinitions: The <fen>Exerter</fen> that can or does exert a force of the level specified by the target.
The <fen>Force</fen> that can or does exert a force of the level specified by the target.
The <fen>Action</fen> that can or does exert a force of the level specified by the target.
The <fen>Time</fen> during which the <fen>Exerter</fen>, <fen>Action</fen>, or <fen>Force</fen> can or does exert its force.
The location where the <fen>Exerter</fen>, <fen>Action</fen>, or <fen>Force</fen> can or does exert its force.
The <fen>Aggressor</fen> is the person causing the <fen>Victim</fen>'s injury.
The <fen>Victim</fen> is the being or entity that is injured.
The <fen>Cause</fen> marks expressions that indicate some non-intentional, typically non-human, force that inflicts harm on the <fen>Victim</fen>
The <fen>Aggressors</fen> commit acts of violence upon each other.
<fen>Time</fen> identifies the time when the harm-causing event occurs.
<fen>Place</fen> identifies the place where the violence occurs.
The <fen>Protagonist</fen> is the entity that tends towards or plans some <fen>Action</fen> which the <fen>Hindrance</fen> causes to be more difficult.
The <fen>Hindrance</fen> is the force which makes the <fen>Action</fen> more difficult or less likely to be successfully completed. The <fen>Hindrance</fen> may be a lack of enabling force:

The <fen>Action</fen> is what the <fen>Protagonist</fen> desires to do, which is made more difficult by the <fen>Hindrance</fen>. It can also be a natural act or collective endeavor, not linked to an overt <fen>Protagonist</fen>.
The <fen>Time</fen> is when the <fen>Hindrance</fen> affects the <fen>Protagonist</fen> or <fen>Action</fen>.
The <fen>Place</fen> is the location where  he <fen>Hindrance</fen> affects the <fen>Protagonist</fen> or <fen>Action</fen>.
This role identifies the first (or only) participant in a competition.
This role identifies the second participant in a competition.
This role is used for plural NP participants in a competition.
This role is used for the name of the competition.
The period of time when the <fen>Competition</fen> occurs.

Where the event takes place. 
A constituent tagged as <fen>Place</fen> may require annotation on a secondary FE-layer.

This Frame Element marks expressions indicating the <fen>Activity</fen> that the <fen>Experiencer</fen> finds difficult or easy. In many cases, the relevant <fen>Activity</fen> has to be inferred from the context.
This Frame Element marks expressions that indicate which person judges carrying out the <fen>Activity</fen> to be easy or difficult.
The time at which the <fen>Activity</fen> takes place.
The <fen>Resisting_entity</fen> is the item that resists the <fen>Opposing_force</fen> to the level specified by the target.

The <fen>Opposing_force</fen> is the item placed in opposition to the <fen>Resisting_entity</fen>. <fen>Opposing_force</fen> hinders, blocks, helps, or allows (lets) the <fen>Resisting_entity</fen> to resist at the level specified by the target. Sometimes this Core role is incorporated in the target; otherwise, it is often null instantiated in example sentences.
The <fen>Time</fen> when the <fen>Resisting_entity</fen> resists an external force.
The location where the <fen>Resisting_entity</fen> resists an external force.
listRoleExamples: Salesmen touted the power <fex>of the engine's motor</fex>.
No one should underestimate the mighty <fex>strength</fex> of the dung beetle.
She gave him a playful, weak <fex>punch</fex> in the arm.
My quads feel particularly weak <fex>after 100 squats</fex>.
Muhammad Ali's force <fex>in the ring</fex> was indisputable.
<fex>Your</fex> brutality on your enemies seems to know no boundaries.
Increasing violence against supporters of government reform have attracted international attention.
<fex>The storm's</fex> violence left many lives in shambles.
Hope for a peaceful resoliton is gone as violence <fex>between the two sides</fex> reignites.
<fex>Last week's</fex> violence resulted in over three hundred injuries.
City leaders are troubled by recent surges in <fex>local</fex> violence
The project was hampered <fex>by a lack of funds</fex>.
<fex>Jo</fex> played the lottery every day.
Jo played <fex>Leslie</fex> at tennis.
<fex>Jo and Leslie</fex> played tennis.
Jo played <fex>in the foosball tournament</fex>
First layer: John's first competition <fex>at Wimbledon</fex> astonished the crowd.
<fex>The climb</fex> was difficult.
The geology question on the exam was hard <fex>for me</fex>.
These are made from a tough <fex>plastic foam</fex> and are very light to wear.
The fortress was impregnable <fex>to attack by hostile invaders</fex>.
The retaining wall was even weaker <fex>yesterday</fex>, and had begun to crumble.
They decided the tree-house would be sturdiest <fex>in the big old backyard oak</fex>.

sourceCandidateSpans.text: the 2nd Battalion of the Queen's Own Rifles
